ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained crucial skills that I anticipate I will need for my future thesis project. By spending time in a completely different department, I gained insight on different lab cultures (and what did/didn't work with it), different questions, different ways of approaching a problem, and different advising styles.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: For me, the rotation was exactly what I needed. It gave me a chance to experience life outside of the EEB department, which is very small. The freedom to choose where to go (within reason) was very valuable and exciting. Weakness: Incoming students could benefit with an explanation of the reasons for doing a rotation. We chose a rotation with the goal of acquiring certain skills and making connections. Others might enter a rotation with the goal of completing a specific project. We weren't given any instruction on this, however, and from talking with some of my cohort they felt that they had 'wasted' their rotation because of this. It might make sense to not require this rotation to occur within the first year, as it is difficult to predict what skills will be needed for their thesis. Perhaps giving the option to do a rotation during any semester of their degree would work better.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
